Award.AwardTitle: US-French Research Proposal: Collaborative Research: Predicting Odorant-dependent and Independent Olfactory Neuron Activation Based on Receptor
Award.AbstractNarration:
Smell is a powerful sense that can trigger intense emotion, stereotyped behaviors and durable memories. The sense offers an extraordinary opportunity to connect atomic-level objects (odorant molecules and smell receptors in the nose) to neural responses. This project will predict which smell receptors in the nose are activated by a given odor. To accomplish this goal, the team of investigators will apply computational approaches to develop chemical structure-based receptor models and test these models using odor molecules interacting with olfactory receptors. The success of the project will enable the team to understand more precisely how the brain perceives the external environment. The results will also have widespread and diverse industrial applications, including rational design of new flavors and fragrances and development of new biosensors for detecting various chemicals. Furthermore, this project will make broader impacts in training and educating high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in various disciplines as well as in outreaching activities.

The complexity of the odor molecules, the large number of the smell receptors and combinatorial activation of the receptors make understanding odor coding an enormous challenge. This collaborative proposal represents the first of its kind that combines computational approaches with experimental measurements at both the receptor and the neuron level. Affinity calculations between odorants and the receptors, as well as the receptors' activation, will be obtained by nanosecond-scale simulations. Atomic-level simulations, initially assessed by experiments, will predict which odors would activate the receptors of interest. Comparisons between experimental findings and computational predictions will lead to a comprehensive computational model that converges with experimental data.

A companion project is being funded by the French National Research Agency (ANR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Smell is a powerful sense that can trigger intense emotion, stereotyped behaviors, and durable memories. The goal of this project is to offer a novel combination of computational and experimental approaches to understand the general rules of odorous molecule detection by mammalian odorant receptors. We developed a methodology based on the cross-talking between molecular modeling, machine learning, site-directed mutagenesis and functional in vitro assay allowing us to unravel the complex interactions between the chemical structure of an odorant and the ligand-binding cavity of the odorant receptors. We first focused on the tuning character of odorant receptors, where some members of the family bind to multiple and diverse odorants, whereas some others are very specific to the binding of a few molecules. We showed that in addition to the properties of the ligand-binding site of the odorant receptor, its ability to switch from an inactive to an active conformation is crucial in the encoding of their tuning character. I picked the case of the most studied narrowly tuned receptor, named OR7D4 and only responsible for the detection of androstenone and androstadienone, to decipher the ligand-dependent activation mechanism of the mammalian odorant receptors. This mechanism relies on several motifs of amino acids highly conserved in this receptor family which work as a network of interactions to assure the communication between the odorant-binding site and the intracellular region of the receptor. We then focused on a member of the fish-like odorant receptors, OR51E1, known to be strongly involved in the detection of odorant possessing a carboxylic acid chemical function which possess odors perceived mainly as unpleasant. We used machine learning models to discover new odorant molecules able to activate this receptor only based on the physico-chemical properties of its known agonists. By getting interested in the motifs of amino acid characterizing the fish-like odorant receptor subfamily, we found that these receptors are specifically binding carboxylic acid molecules thanks to a motif located in the vestibule of the canonical odorant binding cavity. Overall, this study brings a new highlight on how the odorant receptors pass from inactive to active state and how they interact with odorant molecules. It is of main interest as predicting odorant receptor activation will lead to the rational design of flavors and fragrances, which have widespread and diverse industrial applications.
